question: I'm sorry for the screw-up. But I couldn't help it it's too late to go trick-or-treating now. I couldn't help it I had to stop at Penny's for the costume. And you were hungry, remember.
answer: Who's fault is it then if it's not yours? You're the one in charge, Daddy.

question: Yeah.
answer: Look. Those kids are still trick-or- treating. They're still out.

question: Those are the Hoyts.
answer: I don't care. They're out.

question: Can't you see... look out there. Nobody's got their porch lights on anymore. It's too late. Those Hoyt kids are just out to get in trouble. See, they put shaving cream all over that mailbox there. They chopped down Herb Crane's new bushes. Little bastards. Jesus H. Christ.
answer: Why do they do that?

question: Do what?
answer: You know.

question: Break stuff?
answer: Yeah. It's stupid.

question: I guess they're stupid.
answer: Did you do that when you were a kid?

question: Well, yeah. Sort of. Nothing really mean. Me and my pals, me and my brothers. It was kind of funny then. Stealing pumpkins, soaping windows. Stuff like that.
answer: Was it funny?

question: To us it was.
answer: But it's not funny now.

question: It's not funny now. I'm a cop and I gotta listen to all the complaints people make. I'm not a kid anymore. You change.
answer: I bet you did lots of bad things.

question: What are you talking about?
answer: I just think you used to be bad.

question: No. I didn't used to be bad. No sir. Where do you get this stuff? From your mother?
answer: No. She doesn't talk about you anymore.

question: Got here just in time. Go ahead. Jump in line. Maybe you'll win a prize. Go on, Jill. Some of those kids you still know.
answer: I don't want to.

question: Why? Why not? You know these kids from when you went to school here. It hasn't been that long.
answer: It's not that.

question: What then?
answer: It's stupid.

question: It's fun.
answer: I want to go home. I don't like it here.

question: Don't mind if I do.
answer: LaRiviere's having a hell of a time in there. Master of fucking ceremonies.

question: Where's that gun you were bragging on today?
answer: No brag. Just fact.

question: Got you for -- 450, 500 bucks?
answer: See you got Jill tonight. How'd you manage that?

question: Don't forget to move your truck. Some party, huh? Sorry I lost sight of you. I had to step outside for a smoke. You find anybody you know here? There must be some kids you used to know from school. You want to go tomorrow? See your old teachers? Be more fun than hanging out with me all day.
answer: No.

question: No what?
answer: No I didn't see anybody I know. No I don't want to go to school here tomorrow. I want to go home.

question: You are home. There are lots of kids you still know here.
answer: I don't want to be here. Don't worry, I love you, Daddy, I do. But I want to go home.

question: Jesus. Listen, Jill, tell you what. Tomorrow morning, you still want to go home, I'll drive you down. I'll get off work or something.
answer: I called Mommy.

question: What? You called Mommy? Just now?
answer: Yes.

question: Jesus, why?
answer: I... because I want to go home. She said she'd come and get me.

question: Come and get you! Shit! It's a damn half hour drive each way. Why didn't you talk to me about it first?
answer: See, I knew you'd be mad.

question: Yeah. Yeah, right, I'm mad. What'd you tell her, for Christ sake?
answer: I told her I wanted to come home. Daddy, don't be mad at me.

question: Well, I guess I am. I planned this, I planned all this, you know. I mean, it's sort of pathetic, but I planned it. You shouldn't have called your mother. C'mon, we're gonna call her before she leaves. She's gone already! Gone already! Couldn't wait.
answer: Yes.

question: That's all you got to say? "Yes".
answer: Yes.

question: She won't be here for a half hour. Think you can stand it that long?
answer: Yes.

question: Where do you expect to wait for her? Obviously downstairs with the other kids isn't good enough. Sit right there by yourself if you want. Wait for her by yourself. That's fine with me. Just dandy. I'm going downstairs.
answer: That's fine with me too. When Mommy comes, tell her I'm up here.

question: I thought I told you to move that truck!
answer: Relax, Chief. We're leaving. You wanna toke?

question: You gotta be more careful about that shit. Gordon or one of those guys sees you smoking that wacky tabacky around me they'll expect me to bust you. And I'll be outta a job.
answer: Some job. Here, have a hit. Don't be such a hardass. I know you got problems, but everybody's got problems.

question: Not here.
answer: Well, c'mon, then. Get in and we'll take a little ride, my man. Got a job first thing in the morning, first day of season. Saturday I'll hunt for myself. Twombley something. - Er --

question: Evan. He's a mucky-muck union official from Massachusetts. You're lucky.
answer: Don't know about lucky. The guy's a full-blown asshole. Pay's good, though. $100 a day. I got to guarantee a kill, of course. Which I can do. There's some monster bucks hiding out up there.

question: How'd you get the job?
answer: Gordon, he's always got some angle working. He wants to keep Twombley happy, I'm his boy.

question: Toothache. You should get close to him. Make yourself irreplaceable. Guy's loaded.
answer: Like you and Gordon?

question: Right. The sonofabitch couldn't get along without me.
answer: Yeah, he'd go broke tomorrow if you quit him.

question: Right!
answer: Bastard's got his high beams on.

question: Shit. My ex-wife Lillian and her husband. That was them in the Audi that just passed us.
answer: Audi's a good car.

question: Aw, shit, she's here to get Jill. Me and Jill had a little argument. Jack, I got to get back, get back to town. Move this thing, will you? See if you can get back to the Town Hall before they get there, okay?
answer: Piece of fucking cake.

question: Lillian!
answer: Where's Jill?

question: Me and Jill, we just had a little spat. She felt kind of left out, I guess, from not knowing some of the new kids --
answer: Where is she now? Is she in the truck with your friends?

question: She told me she wanted to wait for you. Inside.
answer: While you went off for a few beers with your friends? Is that Hettie Rodgers there, with whatzizname?

question: Yeah.
answer: She's grown up some, hasn't she?

question: Oh, Jesus, lay off, will you? It looks like you've won this fucking round already, so lay off a little, for Christ's sake. Horner! Leave her be. This's got nothing to do with you, so just act like the chauffeur. Got it? I don't want her to go, Lillian.
answer: Don't cause a scene. No one's trying to win any 'rounds'. Don't make it any worse.

question: I'm not making it any worse. You are. Me and Jill could've worked this thing out. It's normal, it's even normal for me to get a little touchy about it. Believe it or not. How do you think this makes me look, treating her like some tragic victim or something? Just wait till we're through, goddamnit! Don't you say a word. I didn't hit him. I'm not going to hit anybody.
answer: New hat? Jill's up, I see.

question: For a while.
answer: How's she doing?

question: Okay. She's fine.
answer: You two want to do anything tomorrow and need a third party, give me a call, okay? I'm off. Well, that's that.

question: You be careful of that little bastard. He's dying to get in your pants, you know.
answer: Don't worry. I can protect my virtue. I mean, c'mon, Wade, give me a break.

question: See you tomorrow, maybe.
answer: You okay?

question: It's not enough snow, not for tracking the bastards. No advantage there, kid.
answer: Don't worry, Mr. Twombley, I know where those suckers are. Rain or shine, snow or no snow. I know deer. We'll kill us a buck today. Guaranteed. Before ten.

question: Guaranteed, eh?
answer: Yep. Right about now the does are holing up in the brush piles. The bucks are right behind them and we're right behind the bucks. This gun gets fired before ten o'clock. Whether it kills a deer or not is more less up to you. I'll put you inside 30, 35 yards of a buck the first four hours of the season. That's what you're paying me for, ain't it?

question: Damn straight!
answer: Done much shooting with that rifle yet?

question: Tell you what. You get me close to a big buck by ten, kid, there's another hundred bucks in it.
answer: If you get it?

question: Yeah.
answer: You might not kill it.

question: You think so.
answer: You might gut-shoot it or cripple it for somebody else to find and tag. Can't guarantee that won't happen, especially with a new gun. I may have to shoot it.

question: You take care of your end, kid, I'll take care of mine.
answer: Mmm.

question: You understand what I'm saying? I want a deer, a dead one, not a cripple or whatthefuck.
answer: I get it. No sweat. You'll get yourself a deer and you'll get him dead. And you'll have him by coffee time.

question: And you'll get your extra hundred bucks.
answer: Wonderful!

question: Safety on?
answer: I'm okay.

question: Follow close. We'll cross the next meadow. I used to play ball.
answer: Yeah?

question: Drafted by the Red Sox.
answer: You played for the Sox?

question: Double A. New Britain.
answer: Oh.

question: Pitcher. "Best ballplayer to come out of New Hampshire since Carlton Fisk."
answer: Really.

question: They said.
answer: Hmm.

question: The only difference between me and that Clemens on TV is luck, shit luck.
answer: What happened?

question: Ruined my arm. Brought me along too fast. Why'd it have to be my fucking arm, I used to think. Then I realized it had to be somebody's fucking arm.
answer: Hey, Hewitt! Slow the fuck down!

question: Safety on?
answer: Yeah.

question: This way.
answer: Sun's gettin high.

question: Told you the snow was coming down. Take the grader.
answer: Where's the plow?

question: Jimmy took it. Jack's out hunting with Evan Twombley.
answer: His son-in-law damn near killed me.

question: Huh?
answer: At the school crossing. In his BMW. Coulda hurt some kids. I'm gonna bust his ass.

question: Don't go playing policeman.
answer: What am I -- a security guard? You hired me, you and your Selectman friends.

question: You don't want the extra police pay?
answer: I'm not saying that.

question: Get the grader. Go out 29 past Toby's. Don't let Lillian get to you. She didn't belong here. That's why she left.
answer: Fuck you.

question: I think we made the point.
answer: You just needed a drink.

question: What was that? You got something to say, say it! Say it!
answer: Nothing.

question: You no-good pup!
answer: It don't look right.

question: It don't look right.
answer: What?

question: The sign. It looks like it's spelled wrong or something.
answer: Fuck. Wade Whitehouse. It's people like you that keep this fucking town from prospering. Whatever somebody does to improve things around here, you gotta find fault with it.

question: I'm not finding fault. It's a good idea, good for you, good for the town. Real modern too.
answer: This town sucks.

question: Aw, c'mon, I was only saying there's something wrong with "Home Made Cooking", that's all. The sign's fine. What it says is wrong.
answer: Who needs it? Everybody who comes here has been coming for years so what they need a sign for? You okay?

question: Yeah.
answer: I'm sorry about what I said.

question: Said what?
answer: About you and Jill and needing a third person. She went back to Lillian?

question: Forget it.
answer: I'm sorry.

question: I'm going to start one of those custody suits. I don't give a fucking shit. You know?
answer: You don't mean that.

question: Yeah. I mean that.
answer: No you don't. You're pissed, that's all. You ought to cool off for a few days then have a long talk with Lillian. You know? Work it out with her, tell her how you feel. Lillian's not out to get you.

question: You talked to Jack?
answer: Not since last night. He took a guy hunting.

question: The fucker shot himself. Ker-bang! That's what it sounds like. Not on purpose. I assume accidental.
answer: Jack?

question: The other guy.
answer: Where... how'd you hear that?

question: CB. Little while ago. One of the boys on the way in picked up Jack on the CB calling for state troopers. I figured you'd know what really happened. The fucking guy kill himself? This Twombley, who the fuck is he, anyhow?
answer: No, I... I've been out on the grader all morning. Twombley's summer people. Massachusetts. Friend of Gordon's. It was his idea for Jack to take him hunting. I gotta go.

question: What's the hurry?
answer: A hunting accident. Jack and Twombley.

question: Huh?
answer: I figured you already heard.

question: Twombley, Jesus. We got to get moving Fuck. Turn it off. All you heard was there was some kinda accident?
answer: Twombley's shot. I heard that. Not Jack. He's okay, I assume.

question: Fuck. You don't know how bad or anything?
answer: You mean Twombley?

question: Yes, Wade, I mean Twombley. Put out that cigarette. Fuck. Fuck. Fuck.
answer: He more than likely just shot himself in the foot or something. That's what usually happens.

question: I shoulda sent you instead of Jack.
answer: I wish you had. I'd rather be deer hunting instead of freezing my ass on that fucking grader.

question: You ain't the hunter Jack is. And he can't drive the grader worth shit.
answer: Like hell.

question: That must've been Twombley. Jesus. I bet that was Twombley.
answer: You want me to follow them to Littleton?

question: Let's get to the top and talk to Jack first. He'll know what happened. He fucking better. If this coulda been avoided, I'll put that kid's ass in a sling.
answer: You heard the news.

question: I hear Twombley got shot.
answer: Yeah.

question: This is gonna be one fucking mess to clean up. Twombley's son-in-law and daughter are up the weekend. Didn't you say you'd seen him, Wade?
answer: I seen 'em. Near ran me over.

question: What the fuck. My day's already ruined. Give me the keys. You can go back with Jack. You still got a shitload of plowing to do.
answer: It ain't done, if that's what you mean.

question: Something bugging you?
answer: Yeah. A few things.

question: Well, right now we're not too interested. Finish up what you gotta do, then you can get bugged on your own time. Might as well take the rest of the day off. You look sort of fucked up. You've been paid for the day, anyhow, right?
answer: Not exactly. I mean, he never paid me.

question: You'll get your money. Don't talk to any newspapers about this. Twombley's a big deal down in Massachusetts, you know. Tell them your lawyer says you shouldn't comment.
answer: Lawyer? I don't need no lawyer, do I?

question: Where'd Twombley get shot?
answer: In the chest.

question: No, I mean whereabouts.
answer: A half mile in, along the old lumber road.

question: You bring him up yourself? That's a steep climb.
answer: The ambulance guys lugged him up.

question: You stayed away?
answer: Yeah.

question: Where'd you get the blood?
answer: What blood?

question: On your sleeve.
answer: Musta... How'd I know? What're you doing, playing cop?

question: I gotta make a report to Fish and Game. I was just wondering, that's all. What'd he do, to shoot himself, I mean?
answer: Who the fuck knows? Musta slipped or something. I just heard the gun go off.

question: I never seen a man shot before. Not even in the service. Must be something.
answer: Well, I didn't actually see him do it. Like I said.

question: Sure you did.
answer: What?

question: Saw him do it?
answer: What the fuck you telling me, Wade? I never seen the guy get shot, I told you that.

question: You musta seen him get shot. I know you did.
answer: Let's get the fuck outta here. You're not making any sense, man.

question: There's your old twenty-gauge, and that there's the new Browning you was showing me last night. This must be Twombley's gun. Brand new. Very fancy tooling. Probably fired one time. It's a beautiful piece of work. But what the hell, Jack, I guess you deserve it. Right's right.
answer: Yeah.

question: Twombley sure as hell won't be shooting it again.
answer: He sure as hell won't.

question: Rolfe.
answer: Wade?

question: Yeah, brother, look, I was calling cause -- has there been anything on TV in Boston about a hunting accident with a guy named Twombley, Evan Twombley?
answer: There was something. It happened up your way.

question: Yeah, I know him -- the kid that was with him. Maybe you do too. Jack Hewitt. He works for LaRiviere with me. He's my best friend.
answer: Wade, it's late. I know you're probably at Toby's, but I'm in bed reading. We got different habits.

question: No, not tonight. I'm in bed too. I'm calling because I need you to listen. You're supposed to be a smart guy. You're a professor. I got this theory. Jack says he didn't see Twombley shot but he did. It'll come out Jack lied and the kid'll get hung for it.
answer: He was scheduled to testify for a committee investigating organized crime in New England and the construction business.

question: Who?
answer: Twombley.

question: No shit.
answer: You think Jack shot him?

question: Well, it was an accident.
answer: They were out deer hunting, right? Jack probably heard the gun go off, then came back and found the body.

question: Lillian was here. In Lawford.
answer: Huh?

question: The night before the shooting.
answer: How was she?

question: Picked up Jill. She was supposed to visit for the weekend for Halloween. She wanted to go home.
answer: Who?

question: Jill. I was thinking of getting a lawyer. Maybe you can help me.
answer: What happened?

question: A divorce lawyer. A custody lawyer. You know, 'cause of Jill.
answer: Don't think about it. You're exhausted.

question: Yeah, I guess.
answer: Get some sleep.

question: I get to feeling like a whipped dog some days, Rolfe, and some night I'm going to bite back. I swear it.
answer: Haven't you already done a bit of that?

question: No, no, I haven't. Not really. I've growled a little, but I haven't bit.
answer: Who are you?

question: I was... I'm Wade Whitehouse. I was wondering, is your husband here?
answer: He's asleep. We were up very late.

question: Well, yes, I'm... I want to say that I'm real sorry about your father, Mrs. Twombley.
answer: Mrs. Gordon. Thank you.

question: Well, yeah, I suppose. Sure. I just had a little business to settle with Mr. Gordon. I'm the local police officer.
answer: Something about my father?

question: Oh, no. No, it's a... it's a traffic thing. No big deal.
answer: Can't it wait, then?

question: Whitehouse. Next time, phone ahead.
answer: How's that?

question: I said, 'Next time, phone ahead.'
answer: Jesus Christ. Mr. Gordon, when I come all the way to serve somebody a summons, I don't call ahead for an appointment.

question: What the hell are you talking about?
answer: I'm issuing you a ticket. Moving violation.

question: Moving violation! I just got out of bed and you're telling me you're giving me a goddamn speeding ticket? Now? Are you nuts? Is that it, Whitehouse? You're nuts?
answer: Yesterday morning, you passed a stopped school bus, which was flashing its lights, then you--

question: Hold on!
answer: Don't ever put your hands on me, Mr. Gordon.

question: You're talking about a goddamned ticket, from when I passed you at the school where you were deciding to hold up traffic while dreaming of becoming a traffic cop or something?
answer: Don't give me a hard time, Mr. Gordon. I'm just --

question: Doing your fucking job. I know. I watch television too.
answer: Yes. Here's your ticket.

question: Jack's sort of sensitive, I guess. More than most. But he'll be okay in a few weeks.
answer: There's something funny about that shooting. There's lots funny about it, actually.

question: I heard he was drunk at Toby's last night and got in a fight with Hettie. He drove off without her...
answer: I'm sure, I'm positive it didn't happen the way Jack says it did.

question: ...Jack's turned into one of those men who are permanently angry. He used to be a sweet kid, but it's like, when he found out he couldn't play ball anymore, he changed. Now he's like everyone else.
answer: I've been wondering if maybe Jack shot Twombley, instead of Twombley shooting himself. I've been wondering maybe Jack shot him on purpose.

question: Wade! How can you even think such a thing? Why would Jack Hewitt do that, shoot Twombley on purpose?
answer: Money.

question: Jack doesn't need money.
answer: Everybody needs money. Except guys like Twombley and that sonofabitch son-in-law of his. People like that.

question: Jack wouldn't kill for it. Besides, who would pay him?
answer: Lots of people. Guy like Evan Twombley, Boston union official, probably got lots of people want to see him dead. The Government's been investigating his links with the Mafia.

question: The Mafia hire Jack Hewitt?
answer: No, I just know Jack's lying about what happened. He just seemed -- I know that kid, what he's like inside. He's a lot like I was at his age.

question: You wouldn't have done anything like that, shot someone for money.
answer: No. Not for money. But, if somebody'd given me half a damned excuse -- I was pretty fucked up, you know.

question: But not now. When you gonna get that tooth fixed?
answer: I can see what you looked like as a kid.

question: You knew me as a kid.
answer: Yeah, but never what you looked like. Not really. Never really studied your face, like now. I was never able to see you as a kid when you were a kid until now, this way.

question: What way?
answer: After making love. I like it. It's nice to see that in a grown-up person.

question: It's nice. Don't you think, do you still think it's a good idea to press this custody thing -- just now?
answer: I'm her father -- supposed to be, but I'm not able to. Yes. Yes, I am. It may be the only thing in my life I've been so clear about wanting. Even if it takes a big fight.

question: Then... I guess you have to.
answer: There's another thing I've been thinking about. I don't know how you feel about the idea, Margie, because we've never talked about it. But I've been thinking lately, I've been thinking we should get married sometime. You and me.

question: Oh, Wade.
answer: I've been thinking about it, that's all.

question: You've been married twice --
answer: It was to the same woman. I was just a kid... It's not like a marriage proposal or anything, just a thought. Something for you and me to talk about and think about. You know?

question: Alright. I'll think about it.
answer: Good.

question: Are you sure they're home? Did you call?
answer: The truck's here. Looks like they've stayed inside since the snow started. Strange.

question: Think they're alright?
answer: Of course! I would've heard.

question: How?
answer: I don't know for Christ's sake! Pop, Pop, you okay? Jesus, Pop, how can you stand the cold, dressed like that? Where's Ma?

question: I don't know for Christ's sake! Pop, Pop, you okay? Jesus, Pop, how can you stand the cold, dressed like that? Where's Ma?
answer: Sleeping.

question: You remember Margie Fogg?
answer: From Wickham's. Been a while. Like some coffee?

question: How you and Ma doing? Haven't seen you in town for a while.
answer: We're alright. Your Ma's sleeping. You want me to get her?

question: Yeah. Jesus. Nothing's changed around here. Where's Ma?
answer: She's coming.

question: She's coming.
answer: Have you been heating the house? Not just with the stove.

question: There's a furnace.
answer: You're not using it today?

question: It's broke I guess. There's an electric in the bedroom.
answer: Maybe Wade should take a look at it. Your pipes'll freeze. Wade, would you do that?

question: Is...? She's dead then?
answer: Yeah.

question: I checked on her. She had the electric heater. Cold don't bother her as much as me. Which is why I give her the heater.
answer: Is there something wrong with the phone?

question: In the living room.
answer: Why didn't you call and have the furnace fixed?

question: I'm glad you're here. Can you stay for a while? You ever come to your father's grave anymore?
answer: No, not anymore. It's too... it's too far.

question: We should talk.
answer: We've done all our talking, Wade.

question: It's just...
answer: Let the past be. I'm sorry about your mother. I liked her. You never know how much women like that suffer. It's like they live their lives with the sound turned off -- and then they're gone.

question: Let's dig out Pop's truck before the skin of the snow freezes up.
answer: What about Margie?

question: What about her?
answer: Well, do you still plan to get married?

question: Yeah. She'll probably quit her job and stay out here with Pop. We can't leave him alone here, he'll set the damn place on fire. With Jill here a lot, it'll be good to have Margie around. Things are going to change in that department, by the way. I got a custody lawyer in Concord. I'm gonna see him tomorrow. All hell's gonna break loose, but it's worth it. I want to let the gas run out. I don't want the bastard driving drunk, and he's always drunk now. After, we'll hide the keys.
answer: Anything new about the shooting? Twombley?

question: I guess it was an accident, like everybody thinks.
answer: Want to know what I think happened?

question: Find them everywhere.
answer: I think your first response to the Twombley shooting was the correct one.

question: Which is?
answer: That it wasn't an accident.

question: Then who shot him?
answer: Well, your friend, I think. Jack Hewitt.

question: Motive. You gotta have a motive.
answer: Money.

question: Who'd pay him that kind of money? Not the mob. They got their own guys. Specialists.
answer: They wouldn't deal with a guy like Jack. Who else benefits if Twombley is suddenly dead?

question: I don't know. You tell me.
answer: Okay. It's likely there are people in the union who don't want Twombley to testify. They probably include his son-in-law who's vice-president and will probably be the next president. I read that in the papers. What's his name, Mel Gordon?

question: Yeah, the guy with the BMW I told you about. I did, didn't I?
answer: Here's my theory. Twombley, unaware of illegal union loans or whatever, starts nosing around cause of the investigation and finds out. Finds out his son-in-law is involved.

question: So Mel Gordon wouldn't want a professional hit. That'd make the feds dig deeper. He wants an accident.
answer: A hunting accident is perfect.

question: Shit, around here, you shoot somebody in the woods, you say it was an accident, you get fined fifty bucks and your hunting license lifted. Jack's probably saying the guy shot himself cause he ain't got his deer yet and don't want his license pulled. It's too neat. Things ain't that neat. It makes me mad. That somebody can pay to kill somebody, his own father-in-law, and not be punished for it. Don't that piss you off?
answer: Not particularly.

question: Right's right, goddamnit! Don't you care what's right?
answer: I care about what happened. The truth. I'm a student of history, remember? I was thinking about that story you told me, about Pop and chopping the firewood out of the ice and after.

question: Yeah.
answer: I hate to disappoint you, but I don't think it happened.

question: Of course it happened. Why would I lie about it?
answer: It may have happened, but not the way you said.

question: You think I wouldn't remember a thing like that?
answer: It wasn't me. I wasn't there, but I heard about it. When I heard about it, it was about Elbourne.

question: We'd have to go digging in Vietnam to ask him.
answer: And Elbourne and Mom took you to the doctor and told him you fell from the hay loft.

question: Well, I never heard that one.
answer: I remember clearly cause when I heard I became real careful around Pop. I was a careful child and I became a careful adult, but at least I wasn't afflicted by that man's violence.

question: That's what you think.
answer: I gotta head back. It's a long drive.

question: Morning, Gordon.
answer: I'm fucking out of here.

question: Lawford?
answer: Out of this fucking job. This job sucks. Working outside in the winter sucks. Open the door, will ya?

question: Why don't you quit now, you want out so bad?
answer: Open the door. We're late.

question: I mean it -- you got enough money now. Head out for California. Surf's up, Jack, and you're digging wells in the snow.
answer: What do you mean I got money? I'm as broke as you.

question: I screwed up the divorce. I agreed with everything she said. I wanted her to like me. I just want to be a good father.
answer: It would help if you were married, if there was someone at home while you work.

question: I plan to. Soon.
answer: How soon?

question: This spring.
answer: Good. It would help if there were some drug or alcohol abuse on the part of your ex-wife. Sexual problems upsetting to the child.

question: It looks pretty hopeless, don't it?
answer: No, not exactly. I'll look at the divorce decree, see if we can get it redrawn. Interview your daughter. Jill, right?

question: Yes.
answer: Fine. I'll need a $500 retainer. You can mail it.

question: Jesus. How much... how much will the whole thing cost?
answer: Hard to say. If we go for custody, depositions, psychiatric evaluations, it could drag on. Ten or twelve thousand dollars. She could win on appeal. If we just want to get the visitation rights redrawn, assuming they're unduly restrictive, it wouldn't be more than twenty-five hundred.

question: Oh.
answer: You might be better off legally as well as financially to just go for the --

question: Yeah. I know. The custody suit thing was just my getting back at her. I'm not as dumb as I look. Whatever you say. I love my daughter. I'll send you the five hundred. Sorry about the long lunch. My clutch is going out again.
answer: You ever think of getting a new car, Wade?

question: On what you pay me?
answer: Elaine! Call Chub Meritt and have him pick up Wade's car, fix the clutch. Use the pickup. I'll bill it to the town. You're the town police officer and the town police officer should have a decent car. You want a new car or not?

question: What do I have to do for it?
answer: Nothing, Wade, I've been thinking. You don't get enough appreciation around here and it's time we changed things a little.

question: I saw Mel Gordon in here this morning.
answer: So?

question: He say anything about the summons I tried to give him? Sonofabitch wouldn't accept it.
answer: Wade, that wasn't smart. Going out right after the man's father-in-law shot himself. Let it go. Call it a favor to me.

question: You? Why?
answer: Mel's doing some business with me. It's nice to do favors for people you do business with. He was in a hurry. No big deal.

question: That was before Twombley was shot. Before he knew.
answer: What's the difference? Take my truck, take a rest -- stop worrying about Mel Gordon. Have you decided what to do with your old man's place -- he going to stay there?

question: Want to buy?
answer: Don't light that in here. I'm allergic.

question: I won't. You interested?
answer: Maybe.

question: You and Mel Gordon?
answer: Could be.

question: Always count on old Wade for a good screwing. Why should I always pay more, sell cheap? Why should you guys make all the money. You and Mel and Jack. Right's right.
answer: Out! Out!

question: He's on to us!
answer: Shit! What are we gonna do?

question: Maybe I can buy him off. I gotta talk to Mel.
answer: You can't buy Wade off.

question: We bought you.
answer: That was me.

question: Wade! Come in! Have a cup of coffee.
answer: You got yourself a computer, Alma.

question: Been putting my files into it. You take sugar and milk?
answer: No. Black.

question: Are you alright, Wade?
answer: Yeah, sure. Why? I got this damned tooth, I got a few things bugging me, like everybody else. But I'm okay.

question: Well, you look... sad. Upset. I don't mean to pry. I'm sorry about your mother. It was a nice funeral.
answer: Alma, I think there's some dirty business going on in this town.

question: Always has been.
answer: This is maybe worse than you and I are used to. What I'm talking about, I'm talking about murder. Among other things.

question: Who?
answer: Evan Twombley, the union boss who got shot. Somebody murdered him.

question: Who?
answer: You know Jack Hewitt, the kid I work with? ...if Jack told the truth, he could be free by the time he's my age.

question: Sometimes things are simpler than you think. Let me ask you a question.
answer: You don't believe me?

question: About Jack? No. Have you checked out the tax bill on your father's farm lately?
answer: I know he's due for the last two years. I was thinking of paying it when the insurance comes in.

question: Has anybody offered to buy it?
answer: As a mater of fact, yes. LaRiviere.

question: This is all the real estate transactions in this town the last year. Most of it unused land. Most of it for little more than the back taxes owed. This is from three years ago. Some difference, huh?
answer: What is the Northcountry Development Association?

question: I went down to Concord to check it out. The president is Mel Gordon. The vice-president and treasurer is Gordon LaRiviere. Those boys are buying up the mountain, Wade. $364,000 this year. I believe that's out of LaRiviere's league.
answer: Twombley involved?

question: No.
answer: He musta found out. They had to get rid of him. And Jack'll get blamed.

question: All the figures show is that Gordon LaRiviere is going to be a very rich man using his position as Selectman. In a year or two, you won't recognize this town.
answer: You sneaky sonofabitch! I've got your number now, Gordon! All these years I actually thought you were a decent man. Can you believe that?

question: You sneaky sonofabitch! I've got your number now, Gordon! All these years I actually thought you were a decent man. Can you believe that?
answer: Wade, you're done. Let me have the shop keys.

question: You two, don't you get it? He's using you. You're his slaves. Jesus Christ, Jack, don't you see that?
answer: The key, Wade.

question: The good news is we haven't got to your car yet. The bad news --
answer: Just tell me when you'll have it fixed.

question: -- the bad news is there's a problem with Gordon's truck what somebody drove through the ice last night. Figured you'd know something about that, Wade.
answer: Yeah. I know about that.

question: LaRiviere says he ain't gonna pay for the fixin' of your car. A couple hundred for the clutch. I got some more bad news. Wanna hear it?
answer: Tell me.

question: Chub says you're fired.
answer: He can't fire me. LaRiviere already did that this morning.

question: He's a Selectman. The town. He said to tell you to turn your badge in and clean out your office. I'm supposed to pull the CB and police light out of your car. They're town property.
answer: What do you mean, you can't take me today? I told you --

question: What do you mean, you can't take me today? I told you --
answer: What on earth is happening to you? Why are you acting this way?

question: It's my tooth! My fucking tooth! I can't even think anymore because of it.
answer: I heard you talking. You got fired this morning, didn't you?

question: Have her back tomorrow night by six.
answer: No problem. Look, I...

question: You make me sick. I can't believe you've sunk so low.
answer: Low as what? What have I done? It's bad to want to see your own daughter?

question: Are we going in this?
answer: Yeah. My car's in the shop. This'll be fine.

question: It's pretty old.
answer: It belongs to Pop.

question: Pop?
answer: Grandpa. My father. It's his.

question: Oh.
answer: How about a Big Mac?

question: Mommy won't let me eat fast food. You know that. It's bad for you.
answer: C'mon, we can always sneak a Big Mac. And a cherry turnover. Your favorite. What do you say?

question: No.
answer: What do you want, then?

question: Nothing.
answer: You can't have nothing, Jill. We need lunch. Mr. Pizza?

question: Same thing, Daddy. Mommy says --
answer: I know what Mommy says. I'm in charge today, though.

question: Okay. So we'll get what you want. What do you want?
answer: Nothing, I guess. I guess I can wait till we get home. Maybe we'll stop by Wickham's for a hamburger when we get to Lawford. That suit you? You always like Wickham's.

question: Okay.
answer: Fine. Oh, Jesus, Jill, I'm sorry. What's the matter, honey? Please don't cry. Please, honey.

question: What are you sorry for?
answer: I don't know. For the food business. I guess. I just thought, you know, we'd sneak a Big Mac on Mommy, like we used to.

question: I want to go home.
answer: You can't.

question: That's illegal, you know.
answer: I know.

question: You're a policeman.
answer: Nope. Not anymore. I'm nothing anymore.

question: Oh.
answer: Jillie, you want a cheese grilled sandwich?

question: Okay, let's go home, then.
answer: Wade, I got a message for you. Jack Hewitt, he's looking for you. Wants you to clear your stuff out of his office in Town Hall.

question: His office. You mean my old office.
answer: Well, I guess -- that's what he said.

question: He got his deer yet?
answer: No, he's out now. Somewhere on the mountain. I'd stay away from him if I were you. He's real pissed.

question: Going somewhere, Margie?
answer: I'm just cleaning out some of this stuff that's built up. For the rummage sale. And some things for the cleaners. And the laundromat.

question: Don't lie to me. You're leaving me, I can see that.
answer: Don't be silly. Hi, Jill.

question: Marg.
answer: Leave me alone! Leave me alone!

question: Leave me alone! Leave me alone!
answer: Leave her alone! Leave her alone!

question: Get in.
answer: I want to go home. Will you take me home?

question: You! By Christ, you -- I know you. Yeah, you goddamn sonofabitch, I know you. You're a goddamn fucking piece of my heart!
answer: You don't know me. You don't know me! So fuck you. Fuck you.

question: Nah-nah-naw! You done done finally done it! Like a man done it. Done it right. I love you, you mean sonofabitch!
answer: Love! What the fuck do you know about love?

question: Love! I'm made of love!
answer: Call it what you want.

question: Everything you know is from me.
answer: Yeah.

question: Bang!
answer: You and me.

question: Where the Christ you going? You sonofabitch, you leave my fucking truck where it is! I need... Give me the Goddamn keys! I need to get me to town!
answer: Crawl!

question: Nothing in the fucking house to drink. Not a fucking thing. My house, my money, my truck -- stolen!
answer: I don't know you. My goddamn father and I don't know you. I know you now. I love you too. Joke. You scared me.
